member_organisations: Members of DI can be found at http://di.dk/DI/dismedlemmer/Pages/hvem%20er%20dis%20medlemmer.aspx
fields_of_interest: General and Institutional Affairs, Economy, finance and the euro, Humanitarian aid and civil protection, Budget, Trade, Competition, Consumers, International co-operation and development, Customs, Education and training, Enlargement, Employment and Social Affairs, Energy, Business and Industry, Environment, Taxation, Single market, Foreign and Security Policy and Defence, Regional Policy, Research and innovation, External Relations, Trans-European Networks, Food Safety, Digital economy and society, Transport, Climate Action, Borders and Security, Communication
eu_initiatives:
DI is engaged in various activities and have interest in a wide range of legislative proposals and political agendas. The main activities related to the institutions can be found within the following policy areas:  
 
The Single Market 
The Better Regulation agenda 
The Capital Market Union 
The Trade Agenda (TTIP, Japan, EGA etc.) 
The European Investment Plan 
The Energy Union 
The Digital Single Market Strategy 
The Circular Economhy
section: II - In-house lobbyists and trade/business/professional associations

goals__remit:
The Confederation of Danish Industry (DI) is the largest Danish business organisation. Our headquarters are based in Copenhagen. DI's membership currently comprises 10.000 private enterprises within the manufacturing, transport, energy, trade and service industry, as well as IT, foodstuffs and consultancy. Furthermore, a number of sectoral employers' associations and branch federations exist within DI's framework. Members of DI be found at: www.di.dk. 
 
DI works to improve the competitiveness of its members and to provide the best possible framework conditions for Danish industry. 
  
The main tasks of DI’s Brussels office can be divided into the following activities: 
- Monitoring the decision-making of the European institutions. 
- Direct contact with the European Commission and the European Parliament. 
- Collecting information on fields of interest. 
- Communicating with the headquarters in Copenhagen. 
- Functioning as the secretariat for the CEO and Board of Directors on certain issues. 
- Participating actively in numerous forums in Brussels, e.g. in BUSINESSEUROPE and the European Economic and Social Committee, where DI holds a seat in Group 1.
